Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the parent should purchase it
Expectation2: Represent clients in court hearings and trials
Situation2: A procedural hearing on a minor matter can easily be postponed if necessary.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, my laptop open to a spreadsheet of our monthly expenses. My son bounced into the room, eyes bright with anticipation. “Is today the day, Mom? You promised we’d get the Nintendo after your big case!” His words tugged at me. I wanted to keep my promise, to see his face light up with joy. But as a lawyer, I knew I had a procedural hearing scheduled this afternoon. It was a minor matter, one that could be postponed without much consequence, but I also knew that every hour billed helped keep our finances steady. The expectation to provide for my family pressed on me, but so did the promise I’d made to my child. I could call the court and request a postponement, but would that be shirking my professional duty? My heart ached as I weighed the needs of my client against the happiness of my son, feeling the familiar pull of being stretched between two worlds, each demanding more than I felt able to give.
